utterances: A lot warmer than here in Michigan.
The Democrats here in Michigan went into this with their eyes open.

They joined with the Republicans and the Democratic governor passed a law created the primary but they allowed candidates to opt out of the contest if they wanted to, and Barack Obama and John Edwards did that.
The party could have opted out of it and said we want to go the caucus route.
They specifically said no, we're going to participate.
And the result was Hillary Clinton got 55 percent of the vote; 40 percent, if you can believe this, voted uncommitted.
Dennis Kucinich was still on the ballot and he got 4 percent and the rest is, you know, kind of inconsequential.
So now the question is, what could they do?
There isn't going to be another primary in Michigan, I can guarantee that.
That would have to be paid for by the state.
It would cost 10 to $12 million; that's what the one in January cost.

The only option is possibly some kind of Democratic caucus system, but the governor, Jennifer Granholm, who was a big cheerleader for the January 15th primary, has said she thinks it would be a travesty if nearly 600,000 Democratic voters in January were disenfranchised by the party saying, that doesn't count.
We're going to do this all over again at a later date.
And of course the candidates have their opinions about the ideas of a caucus or a primary too - the theory that a caucus might favor Senator Obama; a primary might favor Senator Clinton.
Well, a caucus here in Michigan is kind of a misnomer.
Really, what a caucus is, is a party run close primary.

The thing that's interesting about all this speculation that has exploded in the last 24, 48 hours, Neal, is that it seems to be coming a lot from Hillary Clinton and her followers, not only here in Michigan, but nationally.
And you might ask why would Hillary Clinton want a redo of a primary that she already won.
And I think the answer is as she gets closer to the hour of reckoning, she realizes she will never be able to claim these delegates if they're not seated.
It's like owning a diamond ring, but it's in a bank vault and you can't wear it.
What's the use of having it?

And so she's saying, I am willing to risk redoing the result in Michigan, whether it takes caucuses or a primary or whatever in hopes that I can beat Barack Obama again and get the delegates from Michigan.
Here's an e-mail we have from Jeff(ph) in East Lansing, Michigan.
Of those within my circle of friends who are Democrats or tend to vote left or center, I can tell you we all feel like the fix was in for the Michigan primary.
We were told repeatedly by local, state and national news media that our votes on primary day were meaningless and a waste of time.
Now there are many who do want to count the Michigan primary, along with its delegates, as a win for Senator Clinton.
I'd say we'd feel hoodwinked or bamboozled, but those terms are too comical for such a serious matter.
And I think he's right.
A lot of people said - both in Florida and Michigan - hey, this is not going to matter.
Yeah, there's a lot of sympathy for his point of view.
You're absolutely right.
Hillary Clinton herself said last fall leading up to the primary, she said the results in Michigan are meaningless.
We all know that.
She said that.
Now she's saying, well, we've got to count them or if we can't count the ones that I got, we got to do it again so maybe I can win that, and then we can count those.
But I think whoever just wrote this is absolutely correct.
That is the sentiment on the ground in Michigan.
Well, I would not say that's necessarily the sentiment in Florida.
The 1.75 million Democrats turned out.
It was a record turnout in Florida, so that's what has the party here in an awkward position.
To cast aside 1.75 million votes is a difficult thing for a party that talks about not disenfranchising voters.
But do people in Florida believe the election would have turned out the way that it did if people actually campaigned?
Well, it wasn't as if there was a cone of silence over Florida.
You know, people in Florida were actually watching national TV and paying attention to what was going on.
Would it have been closer?
Sure.
Could Barack Obama have won?
Sure, possibly.
But we're always going to be a Clinton-favored state, but, you know, it was an even playing field.
It was a massive turnout.
There was an election.
Let's go to…
Neal, one…
Go ahead.
One thing that Florida and Michigan had in common was that even though there were these primaries and they were different, obviously, the way Adam has described it is different than Michigan's.
Still, none of the candidates actually campaigned in the state.
They stayed away, right, Adam?
When they were actually in Florida, they were nice enough to frequently come in and take money, but not actually talk to any voters that weren't (unintelligible).
Yeah, you can fundraise - yeah, but you don't have rallies.
You don't have speeches (unintelligible)…
But there was a victory rally in Florida, though, by Senator Clinton, the night of the primary.
Well, after she won - yeah, yeah.
Let's get a caller on the line.
This is Scott(ph).
Scott with us from Fort Myers in Florida.
Hey, how are you doing?
Thanks for taking my call.
Go ahead.
I'm sorry.
I had a question.
I'm curious and I'm confused.
If we had another primary and reopened the polling places to revote, since all these places are basically operated by volunteers, why would it cost $25 million?
Adam Smith?
Well, in Florida, they're operated by the division of elections.
They're operated by 67 different elections offices, so it's a major governmental function to run a statewide election in a state as big as Florida.
Okay, but I know that where I vote and where friends of mine vote, everyone in there is a volunteer.
The people standing there handing you buttons and everyone in there is a volunteer, so who makes $25 million off that?
Well, that's the cost estimate for thousands and thousands of voting offices to be staffed and opened and going.
Now you have a bizarre situation where in Florida, you would have the Florida Democratic Party actually paying the state of the Florida to run an election.
I know a lot of people are laughing at that; but maybe they should find another state - secretary of state to run their election.
Thanks very much for the call, Scott.
Thank you.
Bye-bye.
Let's see if we can go now to Jim(ph).
Jim's with us from Detroit in Michigan.
Hi.

I'm a Democratic trustee for one of the predominantly Republican counties in Michigan, and I've got Democrats who have been Democrats for 30 and 40 years who are saying that the DNC wants to take our representatives away from us and maybe we'll just vote Republican.
Hmm.
Is that - so you're favoring a redo in Michigan then?
No, I think it needs to stay the way they do because people said it's - if people wanted to get out, they could have.
And if the candidates wanted to be on the ballot, they could have.
Clinton's name was on the ballot, so was Kucinich.
And - but if it stays the way it is, no delegates from Michigan will be seated at the convention.
Well, if it stays the way it is, no delegates from Michigan will be seated as far as the DNC holding to their position.
But if they don't hold to their position, if they agreed to seat the delegates, then they'll redo has to be done.
There has to be no money spent, and the Democrats who made it out no matter what the weather was aren't going to be upset with the Democratic Party.
Bill Ballenger, what do you think?
Well, no, I think he's right.
Right now, the real question is if the DNC should decide to seek the delegates, the question is how are the delegates divided up?
Because Hillary Clinton would get 55 percent of them, but who would get the other 45 percent?
Would Barack Obama automatically get them?
Frankly, I think that's the most sensible arrangement.
Some people have suggested that.
Just give Barack Obama all the delegates other than the ones that Hillary Clinton won in the primary.

She would net gain maybe 18 delegates compared to Barack Obama from the result in Michigan if that happened; that would not be enough to get her to a majority of the delegates at the national convention.
And if I were Obama, I would accept that kind of a division because he'd still be way ahead of her.
Adam Smith, anybody talking about something similar to that in Florida?
Well, in Florida, the - she would net about 37 delegates ahead of him, which wouldn't be enough either.

One of the ideas that's being talked about, certainly by the Obama - some of the local Obama supporters, is splitting the delegates evenly; that if people are that concerned about giving Florida or Michigan conceivably a voice in the nomination, why not just do it 50-50?
And then you do away with a lot of the questions.
Can I say something about that?
In terms of seating the delegates as allocated on - in our case January 29th, the Obama position is, under no circumstances will that happen.
It was an invalid election where people didn't campaign, and there's no way they'll allow those to be seated.
Jim, quickly.
Yes, the people that I'm dealing with in my county say, excuse me, whether they chose to campaign or not isn't the issue.
We went to the polls; we voted.
We're the people of the United States.
It's the government of the people, not of the Democratic National Committee.
Thanks very much for the call, Jim.
Appreciate it.
Yeah.
Bye-bye.

We're talking with Adam Smith, political editor for The St. Petersburg Times, and Bill Ballenger, editor and publisher of the newsletter, Inside Michigan Politics, about what are the Democrats going to do about Michigan and Florida.
